content:
neville8 said
I want to email 2 large files

I am assuming there is some problem with doing so. Perhaps you could share your issue, as clicking the paperclip allows you to select a file to attach to an email.

Perhaps they are simply to large, that is not something Thunderbird has influence over, it is also why there is a filelink process for large attachments. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/filelink-large-attachments
creator: MattAuSupport

The bug reporting system has this bug which was fixed in V140 and 140ESR. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1971121

Welche Version verwendest du?
creator: wsmwk

content:
Backups of course. No recommended tools.

If the messages are in an account which was defined to Thunderbird as imap then the messages are not lost. If it was defined as pop and you did not elect to have messages kept on the server, and don't have a backup, then seek recommendations for a professional from people you know and trust - not some search on the internet.
creator: wsmwk

content: To "Connexion" (connect) an account to Thunderbird, launch the application, and in the account setup dialog, enter your name, email address, and password to spacebar counter let Thunderbird attempt automatic configuration. If it fails, manually enter your email provider's server settings (IMAP for incoming, SMTP for outgoing) and authentication details (often OAuth2 or username/password) to complete the connection. We always recommend using the secure port as that ensures the connection between your email client and the server will be encrypted. Only use 110 if 995 is not available.
creator: charlotteemma6778
